body: I get that, but I think the potential damage caused by some breakage in one of the most commonly used hooks isn't worth fixing this bug until we have better testing around it (and ideally refactor the code too). Maybe we can make a new function that just prints the hql instead of dry running and that can be used in the meantime as an alternative (and that can e.g. be passed into a gateway hive cli if the user wants to dry run).

Since DAGs can depend on dry_run not sure that we can just flat out remove it, adding a warning would probably be the best idea for now. The proper fix would be using a proper hive parser as you suggested, as well as adding thorough tests (e.g. testing edge cases around line length), and actually validating the results of the existing tests instead of just running them and checking if they had errors. Definitely a lot of work.
Sounds reasonable. I'll close then seems it seems there should be another ticket addressing this more directly as you mention.

@larrywongl We can't cancel a job for now, not sure if the API expose the feature (but it might). But for what I've seen, it would be way more complex to code (I'm not sure if there's a hook for when a task failed because of timeout). But you can go manually in the jenkins interface and abort the job and that will make the airflow task to fail.

Edit : After a quick search https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21021905/how-to-stop-a-build-in-jenkins-via-the-rest-api to stop a job through API, I don't think it's already exposed in the library but it's possible to send the request at least. And this PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2644 does something similar. But I think it would be better to do this in another PR to merge this one as it is.
@rupesh92 the commit message should be limited to 50chars only.
LGTM

From: Moe Nadal [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Friday, September 29, 2017 3:20 AM
To: apache/incubator-airflow <incubator-airflow@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Wang, Larry <Larry.Wang@emc.com>; Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [apache/incubator-airflow] AIRFLOW-1551 : Add an operator to trigger job in jenkins from Airflow (#2553)


@larrywongl<https://github.com/larrywongl> We can't cancel a job for now, not sure if the API expose the feature (but it might). But for what I've seen, it would be way more complex to code (I'm not sure if there's a hook for when a task failed because of timeout). But you can go manually in the jenkins interface and abort the job and that will make the airflow task to fail.

—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2553#issuecomment-332937621>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZvtkypo8wOEoUTshZRXWEMaScrqKH1bks5sm_F6gaJpZM4PIJyw>.

All bigQuery operators use the BigQuery hook. You can take a look to the contrib/hooks folder, and then all operators related to the same system should use the hook. For another simple example of adding a connection/hook/operator, you can take a look at this PR : https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2553 (the goal is to allow triggering jobs on different jenkins server from airflow)

If you need a feature, create a ticket for it in the bug tracker of airflow and you're more than welcome to write the code for it, that's the principle of open source project. I think this PR cover pretty well the scope of the initial ticket : being able to trigger a job on a jenkins server from airflow. And as shown in the example dag I put in the PR, you can also use a basic python operator to take other actions than the one shipped with the operator.
@bolkedebruin my OS is not running on UTC, how to make this change works on my case? Thanks!

I can do that, but it is assumed you are running in UTC anyway. We now Made it consistent which alles you to run in non UTC environments.

Took a while. I've extended the tests with a more complicated path `etc.airflow.config.custom_airflow_local_settings.LOGGING_CONFIG`. This caused the tests to fail because the temporary path that I was creating required those `__init__.py` files for Python 2.7.
@NielsZeilemaker Is this something that you're still working on?  We're interested in the same feature so happy to push this over the finish line if needed.
Can you make this a real test please? Test the function in the hook

I don't know how else to test this change tbh, because the only thing you could check would be if the shutdown post actually killed the running druid task. This, however, would require a running Druid instance.

What I can add is an assert_called check to see if the URL was called in the function. Seems to me that this should be done for all calls to druid from the druid hook (not just this change). Will make these changes
Perfect!
It would be nice if you could add a screenshot of how this change affects the layout.
This is really useful 👍
The JIRA looks different from the PR
argh, i see now this is being addressed now in https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2631

my thinking on this was that `logging_config_path` could point to a json file that could be `json.load`ed, and the resulting dict could be passed to `logging.config.dictConfig`. Its a bit annoying and not entirely necessary requiring an importable object on the python path (supporting `logging_config_path=/path/to/my/config.json` would be nice), but maybe this can be a follow up issue.

One minor point to add to the updating docs, and I think it should be called out explicitly in UPDATING.md that to use S3Log or GCSLogs you will need a custom logging config -- otherwise people would miss it unless they checked the comment in the default template which they might not.
@ashb Thanks, I've made it more explicit.

I've added a more detailed description to the commit.

As far as a test goes I'm not sure how to write a test for this for the following 2 reasons:
* External Database? (glancing at [1](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/tests/hooks/test_dbapi_hook.py) of the 2 existing hook tests it looks like mock is the answer but i'm not familiar with it...)
* Needs a jar file? (No idea how to solve this without adding a jar file to the airflow package which seems wrong)
  * if theres no jar file both implementations fail with the same error message `Class org.postgresql.Driver not found`

However, here is a test script that demonstrates airflow's current issue along with setup & teardown instructions (Requires macos)

```python
import jaydebeapi
import os

## Requirements
# brew cask install postgres
# pip3 install -U jaydebeapi
# download postgres jdbc driver to downloads folder
# https://jdbc.postgresql.org/download/postgresql-42.1.4.jar

jdbc_driver_name = 'org.postgresql.Driver'
login = os.getlogin()
host = 'jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/' + os.getlogin()
psw = ''
jdbc_driver_loc = '/Users/' + os.getlogin() + '/Downloads/postgresql-42.1.4.jar'


try:  # This is the new JDBC Hook code
    good_conn = jaydebeapi.connect(jclassname=jdbc_driver_name,
                                   url=str(host),
                                   driver_args=[str(login), str(psw)],
                                   jars=jdbc_driver_loc.split(sep=","))
    print('Good succeeded')
except Exception as e:
    print('Good failed with error', e)

try:  # This is the old JDBC Hook code
    bad_conn = jaydebeapi.connect(jdbc_driver_name,
                                  [str(host), str(login), str(psw)],
                                  jdbc_driver_loc,)
    print('bad succeeded')
except Exception as e:
    # fails with
    # No matching overloads found. at native/common/jp_method.cpp:117
    print('bad failed with error', e)


## Cleanup
# brew cask uninstall postgres
# brew cask zap postgres
# rm ~/downloads/postgresql-42.1.4.jar
```

@danielvdende You are not using the `Hook` to do the tests. You basically do a post in your tests. In other words you are not testing the code you have written. Instead of showing successful tests show me changed coverage

`Coverage   71.75%   71.75%   -0.01%     `
@sekikn done.
@msumit Thanks!
Tests crushed without a reason
Master is failing, this needs to be fixed first.

There is no feedback in jobs logs. Could the problem be with those tests themselves? In previous pull request I had same output in 1 of containers, then I re-pushed my code, tests re-run and all of them passed.

@bolkedebruin the post/get statements in the tests are the mocks used per test case. Each test case contains a single call to the Hook, after which the assertions check that each mock was called once (or in some cases called at all). It can be checked that this is the case by moving the assertions to before the call to the hook, this will cause them to fail.

The reason the coverage isn't changing is that the lines of code were actually "tested" previously, but there weren't any assertions on the output or behaviour of these lines.

>  Is there anything not in contrib which can be using the docker hook ?

I don't think so. The Docker operator seems special in that you can use it just fine without a hook. Moving the operator to `contrib/` looks like a breaking change for anyone who's built something on top. Having said that, if nobody objects, I'd leave the operator where it is and add the hook in `contrib/`.

My bad, I didn't realize the docker operator was already available in the codebase, and in this case, moving it will definitely be a breaking change. 
Having the hook is more a way to factorize all docker related operations at one place (in the case you have sensors, different operators, etc...). 
I would go to have the operator and the hook in the same code area (so not putting the hook in contrib) to ease file navigation, but I'm just a newbie here so I'll let more experimented contributor answer this point :).
@r39132 @criccomini @artwr @ldct opened a new PR (https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2657), where hardcoded things can go to respective operators. Plz review that.
